ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This is very much a pre-professional course. We learned a lot about the publishing and editing industry, especially books and magazines. We didn't learn all too much about actually editing, just about the methodology and philosophy of editing.

The class provides a really helpful interactive, hands-on approach to understanding the editing and publishing world. Being taught by Meghan and hearing from guests who are also accomplished in the field was amazing.
I learned a lot about how to edit and the editing life.
I gained valuable insight into the editorial profession and its many sub-fields, and improved my ability to read and critically assess work before editing and publishing it.
I gained an insight into different kinds of editing, and a better idea of what jobs in the field look like.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: in-depth look into the publishing industry. Access to engaging guest speakers.
Weakness: expectations were not very clear and feedback was not timely. Didn't get to practice editing much or get much feedback on editorial exercises.
I enjoyed our many guests from the industry.

This course had an amazing roster of guest speakers, and the class discussion was always engaging. I wish more attention had been paid to the assigned readings (both selecting them and discussing them) as well as to the graded assignments. In addition, I received no graded work throughout the course, so it was difficult to improve my performance or gauge how I was doing:
I think the course is well organized for someone who has had editing practice, but may have been much more challenging and confusing if Id come into it with less practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in going into publishing, yes. If you want to learn to be a better editor, you may be better off taking an english class that involves a lot of peer editing.
Yes, if youre interested in anything related to the world of editing post-grad! It was also really valuable to take as someone working on an on-campus publication currently.
Meghan was a wonderful teacher, and it was exciting to learn more about The Yale Review.
This course would only be advisable for someone with a demonstrated interest in becoming a professional editor.
I would, but only if they are already very interested in editing.
